Anyway, to expand this video's coverage, one-way mirrors (or two-mirrors) have partially-reflective compound such as a thin layer of nearly-transparent material such as aluminium (in contrast to tin chloride and silver which is used in ordinary mirrors). A true one-way mirror that actually allows light to be transmitted in one direction only without requiring external energy is not possible as it violates the second law of thermodynamics: if one placed a cold object on the transmitting side and a hot one on the blocked side, radiant energy would be transferred from the cold to the hot object. Thus, though a one-way mirror can be made to appear to work in only one direction at a time, it is actually reflective from either side." - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mirror

It made sense to me. So you know how when you look into a window and you can kinda see your reflection? That is the same in mirrors. Only some of the light is reflected and only some isn't(so you can see through). Now in a dark room where there isn't much light, not much light is reflected into the mirror, and not much(this is key) goes through so the person on the other side cannot see you and you don't see your reflection. On the other hand, the light room does have light so it goes through(other people in other room can see the 50% that goes through) and the people inside only see the 50% that reflects. This causes it to be "1-way". This concept probably needed a little more time to explain, but it still made sense this way.

Dear Henry

I used to love your videos because every time I finished watching any of them, I felt I learned something new. Unfortunately, I'm afraid I can't say the same about these 10-second videos.

Although I do enjoy learning new stuff related to physics and scientific branches related to it, I am not a physicist myself so my knowledge about the subject is rather limited. That is why I loved your "long" videos, because they provided enough information to understand the subject you're discussing. Although that is not the case with these short videos, it can be argued that they have an educational role - perhaps they are supposed to make us curious and force us to do some research on our own in order to acquire new knowledge. However, the problem about doing the research is that it certainly takes more time and we would probably have to go through quite a bit of the information we do not really care about in order to find the explanation for the subject you have started. I think you should consider that probably the majority of your followers are not physicists and do not care really about about in-depth reading - if we did, we would study physics at university or at least buy a physics coursebook. Most of us who watch these videos just enjoy learning that one tiny bit of information we're probably never even going to need throughout our lives.

As far as we, your audience, are considered, perhaps we tend to forget that the purpose of your existence is not to make videos for us and do what we want you to do. In fact, it's the other way around - this is your channel and you should be making whatever kind of videos makes you satisfied, and if we happen to like them, we should feel grateful. Therefore, you are absolutely free not to take into account anything I have written here and should proceed doing what makes you happy.

In case you actually read this, thank you for your time. Best regards and keep up the good work.
